document.docAuthor: Huang, Jia, Wang, Yalian, O’Grady, Patrick Michael, Su, Yirui & Chen, Hongwei
document.docTitle: Leucophenga brevitabulata Huang & Wang & O’Grady & Su & Chen 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Leucophenga (Diptera, Drosophilidae), part VIII: twenty-one species from the Oriental region, with morphological and molecular evidence

heading.emphasis:
Leucophenga brevitabulata Huang & Chen
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species is most similar to
L . fuscipalpula
sp. nov.
in the colour patterns of abdominal tergites in both male ( Fig. 10D, I ) and female ( Fig. 10E, J ), but can be distinguished from the latter in having the paramere basally narrow ( Fig. 26C ); aedeagus apically hook-shaped, laterally with a long, acute, distoventrally expanded process ( Fig. 26D ); see below for that species.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 26.
Leucophenga brevitabulata Huang & Chen
,
sp. nov.
, male terminalia in lateral view. A. Epandrium, surstylus, and cercus; B. Hypandrium, paramere, gonopods, aedeagus, and aedeagal apodeme; C. Paramere; D. Aedeagus. Scale bars = 0.1 mm.

Etymology. A combination of the Latin words: “
brevis
” (= short) and “ tabulatus ” (= plate), referring to the abdominal 3rd tergite shortened in males.
